Standard Errors of Standardized Estimates of Regression Coefficients (Yuan and Chan (2011))

Source: R/sehat.R
dot-sehatslopesprimedelta.Rd

Standard Errors of Standardized Estimates of Regression Coefficients (Yuan and Chan (2011))

.sehatslopesprimedelta(
  slopes,
  sigma2hatepsilonhat,
  SigmaXhat,
  sigmayXhat,
  sigma2yhat,
  adjust = FALSE,
  n,
  X,
  y
)

Arguments

slopes

Numeric vector of length p or p by 1 matrix. The vector \(\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}_{2, \cdots, k}}\) is a \(p \times 1\) vector of estimates of \(p\) unknown regression slopes.
sigma2hatepsilonhat

Numeric. Estimate of error variance.
SigmaXhat

p by p numeric matrix. Estimated \(p \times p\) variances and covariances of \({X}_{2}, {X}_{3}, \cdots, {X}_{k}\) \(\left( \boldsymbol{\hat{\Sigma}}_{\mathbf{X}} \right)\).
sigmayXhat

Numeric vector of length p or p by 1 matrix. Estimated \(p \times 1\) covariances between the regressand and the regressors \(\left( \boldsymbol{\sigma}_{\mathbf{yX}} \right)\).
sigma2yhat

Numeric. Estimated variance of the regressand \(\left( \hat{\sigma}_{y} \right)\)
adjust

Logical. Use \(n - 3\) adjustment for small samples.
n

Integer. Sample size.
X

n by k numeric matrix. The data matrix \(\mathbf{X}\) (also known as design matrix, model matrix or regressor matrix) is an \(n \times k\) matrix of \(n\) observations of \(k\) regressors, which includes a regressor whose value is 1 for each observation on the first column.
y

Numeric vector of length n or n by 1 matrix. The vector \(\mathbf{y}\) is an \(n \times 1\) vector of observations on the regressand variable.

See also

Other standard errors of estimates of regression coefficients functions: .sehatbetahatbiased(), .sehatbetahat(), .sehatslopesprimetb(), sehatbetahatbiased(), sehatbetahat(), sehatslopesprimedelta(), sehatslopesprimetb()

Examples

slopes <- c(-3.0748755, -1.5653133, 1.0959758, 1.3703010, 0.1666065)
SigmaXhat <- matrix(
  data = c(
    0.25018672, 0.00779108, -0.01626038, -0.04424864, -0.13217068,
    0.00779108, 0.12957466, 0.01061297, -0.08818286, -0.16427222,
    -0.016260378, 0.010612975, 0.133848763, 0.004083767, 0.658462191,
    -0.044248635, -0.088182856, 0.004083767, 7.917601877, -5.910469742,
    -0.1321707, -0.1642722, 0.6584622, -5.9104697, 136.0217584
  ),
  ncol = 5
)
sigma2hatepsilonhat <- 42.35584
sigma2yhat <- 62.35235
sigmayXhat <- c(-0.8819639, -0.3633559, 0.2953811, 10.1433433, 15.9481950)
n <- 1289
.sehatslopesprimedelta(
  slopes = slopes, sigma2hatepsilonhat = sigma2hatepsilonhat,
  SigmaXhat = SigmaXhat, sigma2yhat = sigma2yhat, sigmayXhat = sigmayXhat, n = n
)
#>      sehatslopesprime
#> [1,]       0.02282716
#> [2,]       0.02317122
#> [3,]       0.02342286
#> [4,]       0.02113537
#> [5,]       0.02330714
